name: External Initialization of Trusted Variables or Data Stores
description: The product initializes critical internal variables or data stores using inputs that can be modified by untrusted actors.
extended_description: A product system should be reluctant to trust variables that have been initialized outside of its trust boundary, especially if they are initialized by users. The variables may have been initialized incorrectly. If an attacker can initialize the variable, then they can influence what the vulnerable system will do.

common_consequences.note: An attacker could gain access to and modify sensitive data or system information.

description: A product system should be reluctant to trust variables that have been initialized outside of its trust boundary. Ensure adequate checking (e.g. input validation) is performed when relying on input from outside a trust boundary.
Avoid any external control of variables. If necessary, restrict the variables that can be modified using an allowlist, and use a different namespace or naming convention if possible.

demonstrative_examples.text:
<Intro_Text>In the Java example below, a system property controls the debug level of the application.</Intro_Text>
               <Example_Code Nature="Bad" Language="Java">
                  <xhtml:div>int debugLevel = Integer.getInteger("com.domain.application.debugLevel").intValue();</xhtml:div>
               </Example_Code>
               <Body_Text>If an attacker is able to modify the system property, then it may be possible to coax the application into divulging sensitive information by virtue of the fact that additional debug information is printed/exposed as the debug level increases.</Body_Text>

<Intro_Text>This code checks the HTTP POST request for a debug switch, and enables a debug mode if the switch is set.</Intro_Text>
               <Example_Code Nature="Bad" Language="PHP">
                  <xhtml:div>$debugEnabled = false;<xhtml:br/>if ($_POST["debug"] == "true"){<xhtml:div style="margin-left:1em;">$debugEnabled = true;</xhtml:div>}<xhtml:br/>
                     <xhtml:i>/.../</xhtml:i>
                     <xhtml:br/>
                     <xhtml:br/>function login($username, $password){<xhtml:div style="margin-left:1em;">if($debugEnabled){<xhtml:div style="margin-left:1em;">echo 'Debug Activated';<xhtml:br/>phpinfo();<xhtml:br/>$isAdmin = True;<xhtml:br/>return True;</xhtml:div>}</xhtml:div>}</xhtml:div>
               </Example_Code>
               <Body_Text>Any user can activate the debug mode, gaining administrator privileges. An attacker may also use the information printed by the phpinfo() function to further exploit the system. .</Body_Text>
               <Body_Text>This example also exhibits Information Exposure Through Debug Information (CWE-215)</Body_Text>

Does not clear dangerous environment variables, enabling symlink attack.

notes.text: Overlaps Missing variable initialization, especially in PHP.

<xhtml:p>This is often found in PHP due to register_globals and the common practice of storing library/include files under the web document root so that they are available using a direct request.</xhtml:p>
